If you are referring to violence… no, not really. The only guns I have ever seen have been carried by the military, police, or hunters. So if you do not want to get shot, do not invade, commit a crime, or look like a whitetail deer.  (don’t be this!) I contend the most dangerous part about living in the US is its weather. Sure, you get the occasional torrential rain from a hurricane such as Harvey, but it is the everyday weather that can kill you, too. The summers in most of the US are extremely hot. There are very few places in the US that do not regularly see 100°F/38°C temperatures at least once during the summer months. And when you do, more than likely it is extremely humid, as well. With that extreme humidity, the chances for convection thunderstorms are always prominent. Although not as large or devastating as the aforementioned hurricanes, they produce a lot of rain locally. They also indicate a greater chance of a tornado being produced.  The winters for the northern half of the US are also dangerous. Temperatures well below freezing are frequent - usually in the 0°F/-17°C area. And those are not the extreme temperatures. It can get to -30°F/-34°C fairly easily.  And there are many parts of the US that see both of these extremes. In most of the US, you have to pay attention to the daily weather report, otherwise you are taking a big chance.
